Riley's Parents (from inside out) both have brown eyes and brown hair. For Riley to have blonde hair and blue eyes her parents would both have to carry recessive genes and both pass on only those recessive genes. The likeliness of this happening is very slim (6.25% chance). Also when the movie starts we see Riley's mom holding baby Riley. Her parents appear to be standing up (and her mother looks nothing like a woman who just gave birth) as if Riley has just been handed to them by a nurse. This is obviously Riley's first encounter with her parents. Also Riley's mother is wearing a pink v-neck t-shirt and not a hospital gown. Because of theses reasons Riley's mother is probably not the woman who just gave birth to her. So, who is? Riley's name is Riley Andersen. Bonnie's last name (from toy story 3) is also Anderson (there could have been a family dispute about the spelling of the name which is why they spell it slightly differently). Andy was a little irresponsible in collage. Him and his girlfriend weren't as careful as they should have been and Andy's girlfriend gets pregnant. Andy and his girlfriend then decided to give their unborn child (Riley) up for adoption. While Andy and his pregnant girlfriend were looking for a nice couple, Andy discussed the issue with Bonnie's mom (because the families seemed to be rather close). Bonnie's mom then recommended her younger brother in law and his wife as potential adoption candidates (Riley's parents as seen in inside out, who look a lot like Bonnie's family). This wife was unable to have children and would be more than happy to adopt andy's baby. This would explain Riley's resemblance to andy's mom and Molly and her adopted parents resemblance to Bonnie's family. It also has been confirmed that andy's house, Bonnie's house, and sunny side are all located in an unnamed tri-county area in CA. Although it's obvious that Riley's family moved to San Francisco for her fathers job, her parents also could have moved there to be closer to family (Bonnie's family). In one memory Riley is seen playing on the playground at sunny side (the only difference is the slide but the playground could have just gotten a new slide). So she obvioudly visited California when she was younger and Bonnie's mom (her aunt) could have brought her to sunny side for a day. Another reason why we know that Riley is in the same area as the toy story movies is (this one is a bit of a stretch) at Riley's school a blue eyed brunett is seen where a scull shirt similar to Sid's (who grew up near Andy and became a garbage man for that area). This could be Sid's daughter or niece. Also, in Up Ellie is told she can't have kids. This could be genetic. Ellie could be mrs Anderson's (Riley's mom) aunt. Ellie would therefore be related to Bonnie's family through marriage so Bonnie's mother and Ellie could very well know each other. This would explain how Andy also knows Carl and Ellie and why he has a post card addressed to them.

commentText: This movie didn't deserve to win the Oscar, no. 'When Marnie Was There' was ten times better. Watch it and you'll see. It made me cry buckets of tears.

replies.commentText: Agreed.
I know right!!!!
I don't know why it wasn't chosen. It was so much better than this.
+Princess Anna Studio Ghibli knows how to give you them feels
+Princess Anna Marnie may have been sad and whatnot, but it's nothing new. Inside Out was extremely creative and original.

+Brian Merritt Marnie was fantastic to me!! This movie is great, and I respect it, but I just found Marnie to be a lot better, with the storyline and especially the hand drawn animation. I'm not really a huge fan of CGI, I mean I don't hate it, but I prefer hand drawn. The storyline of Marnie just really appealed to me, and I loved the mystery to it. This movie was just a little too predictable.

Here's what I have to say: I've never found a movie quite like Marnie. But this movie.... this is the same as Up, Finding Nemo, and Toy Story. Original? I think not. In each of those movies, there's the one character, (Joy, Carl, Woody, Marlin) teamed up with a character they don't like so much (Sadness, Russel, Buzz, Dory) who set out to get back/get to somewhere or something (Headquarters, Paradise Falls, Andy's house, Nemo). It's the same thing, over and over. I respect some of Pixar's other films, such as Brave or Monsters Inc., but this... not really. I definitely wouldn't call this ''original''.

+Princess Anna The Oscars don't discriminate CGI. We only think Inside out was predictable because after the fact it seemed formulaic in terms of narrative structure, which to the bare bones yes it may have been, but in detail it was a very creative and original movie, as opposed to Marnie which, yeah, it was great, but Oscars have already been awarded to hand drawn Japanimation style, and whole "feels" thing is something we are used to by now. They've been given their credit.

+Brian Merritt Studio Ghibli has only been given one Oscar, and that was for ''Princess Mononoke''. Oscars are a really big deal, and it seems like every single year Disney wins in the animated film category. Last year, Ghibli's "The Tale of Princess Kayuga" lost out to "Big Hero 6" The year before, "The Wind Rises" lost to "Frozen". Ghibli movies tell a story that just sticks with you. The music is beautifully composed, the characters- well, Disney is a lot better when it comes to characters and personality, but either way, Ghibli does such a good job with their films, and it's a shame they've only won once.
+Brian Merritt My sister was very into Inside Out and Frozen, but these days the DVDs gather dust, while we still take The Princess Kayuga out to watch again and again.
+Princess Anna That's YOUR opinion. Opinion, as in taste.

+Princess Anna I personally think that Frozen is one of the most overrated films in the last decade. It wasn't a bad film, but I felt that it did very little new and that Disney had created far better works in the past. In comparison, The Wind Rises was a beautifully crafted farewell to Hayao Miyazaki and it's an absolute crime that it didn't win the Oscar. There's even less justification for Kaguya not winnning. A 100% on Rotten Tomatoes and considered by many to be one of the best animated films in years, it should absolutely have won. Big Hero 6 is good, great even, but why would they give the award to the film INSPIRED by Japanese animation and not the actual Japanese anime itself? I think it's just more proof that the Oscars are largely ignorant when it comes to animation. Same thing when it comes to foreign films. There's a lot of great Japanese films that I'm pretty surprised didn't make the nomination in previous years.

I'm just wondering why is Desire not among the cartooned emotions in the film Inside out. The film has Joy, Sadness, Fear, Anger, and Disgust but there is no Desire. (No spoiler here, they were all introduced in the trailers.) The filmmakers may justify that they need to limit the characters but Desire is such an important emotion to be left out. Desire, drive, or passion helps in steering our thoughts and actions. Desire can be an unruly emotion that often lands us in mischief if unguarded, but it can also be a driving force for us to achieve something if we just channel it positively. What if there is Desire in Inside Out? How would they draw him/her? How would the story go?

commentText: I look a lot of people asking if there emotions inside of emotions. Well, yes, the most probably thing is, yes. Here's my theory: Emotions doesn't feel always like their names. For example: Joy doesn't feel joyful always, like when she was on the memory dump, she was not joyful, she was sad. When Bing Bong dies, every time an island falls, she wasn't joyful. And also, when she and Sadness were in the subcontanious, she was afraid. Also sadness. And if you take a little look to the movie, the emotions not always are like they are supossed to be. So like the emotions are not always acting like their names, that means that they have anothers type of feelings. So the emotions have emotions, with have emotions, with have emotions, with have emotions, and the circle will never end

replies.commentText: Except that this is actually good
+TheAnimatorOfficial Idk man. I really enjoyed that movie and the animation was great! Too much cgi these days... I kinda miss watching a movie animated like that.
+OldSchoolHipHopHD nostalgia critic anyone? lol

+OldSchoolHipHopHD This is like they took the idea of Osmosis Jones and decided to make a really good movie instead of a Chris Rock buddy movie inside the body of Bill Murray... who didn't seem to be trying to do anything in that film, including acting or be funny. He stuffs his face with cheese puffs while explaining "Your mom didn't die because she was unhealthy, she died because she was sick." in a tone thats all like "silly rabbit, tricks are for kids!", what the hell was up with him in that movie?

+OldSchoolHipHopHD Also while the animation in Osmosis Jones is superb, there was computers used aplenty to animate it, and the cold pill characteris a cgi model. I do like traditional 2d animation aswell, but I think when kids say animated, they think of cgi these days, its just the way the times have gone and in fairness, it takes just as much work if not more to make a beautiful cgi world and character as it does to draw and animate them by hand. I'm more of traditional 2d hand drawn guy myself, but Inside Out was a gorgous film to look t on a big screen.
+OldSchoolHipHopHD More like Herman's Head but actually good. Still, the story felt too overused to me. Too much like Toy Story's.
+OldSchoolHipHopHD ahhhh good ol childhood days

+OldSchoolHipHopHD Can someone explain to me how this is even remotely similar to Osmosis Jones? I haven't seen it since I was a kid but wasn't it about the immune system? Sure, it gave blood cells and viruses personalities, but this movie is about how the emotions work to affect how you behave and react to the world around you. What am I missing in this comparison? Just curious.

+Tyrion Lannister The one similarity I find in Osmosis Jones is when the president uses to the override switch which was located on a panel in the brain. It also was in front of a giant, oval screen that showed the person's vision. There's also the bit where dreams were shown as movies.
+Zatchooze Naut Ohh, yeah... I can see where people would draw on those similarities now. Thanks! I still think Inside Out was amazingly written, though.
+OldSchoolHipHopHD nope. this is so much better than that.
+OldSchoolHipHopHD When I was young, I only watched the show, but not the movie. Hell, the show motivated me to watch Inside Out.
+OldSchoolHipHopHD Not quite the same... Osmosis Jones and his ilk represent cells. These represent thought processes!

+Tyrion Lannister Its similar in the way that both movies are focused on whats happening in the human body and the feelings and cells are the characters to try and keep the human safe, happy and healthy.

commentText: For you guys wondering, the people inside her head are boys and girls because she has some of her father and some of her mother. They are in fact younger versions (like her father's anger in the other trailer has a moustache but otherwise is identical to Riley's anger). It's like genes, and she will probably develop female ones later in life, after puberty. Puberty is also about finding yourself (what if one were to turn out transgender, you need gender options). It's logical, because she is not yet fully female.

So here is my life (You can ignore this comment if you want): I started my life in Canada. The people there were great, and everything was perfect. I made a lot of nice friends and had a lot of fun.I made almost all of my good memories there. Instead of hockey, I've developed an eager passion for soccer. I've played peewee soccer for about a year, and it was pretty fun to meet new people on the soccer team. We lived there for about 12 years, until we took an unexpected turn and moved to Korea. At first, I was excited, but i was also sad for having to lose my friends that i've known for a lifetime. I tried to keep positive, but things took a serious downhill overtime. As soon as school started, I was all alone. The people there were mean and racists. Soon, I starting to get depressed, lonely, and even had some suicidal thoughts. One time, I couldnt take it anymore and spent about a month on getting plane tickets and escaping to Canada. But i knew i couldnt do it, so i just decided to stay in Korea. Is been 3 years now, and I've lost my passion for soccer, lost all self confidence, and have depression, anxiety, social issues, and lonliness. I'm 15 now, and have lasted 3 years in hell. This is why i can connect to the movie "Inside out" so much.

+Jimin Yu (Jimbob Jimmy) I could also relate to this movie in the sense that I moved away from "home" when I was 13. A new city, new school and new people. I never really made any friends, not any worth keeping anyway, and it was an extremely lonely and confusing time for me. I'm 23 now, still living in the "shitty" town I moved to at the age of 13... But I've started to like it here, I've decided to look past the people and focus my love on to the scenery that surrounds my city. I learned a lot from being "transported" away from the only safe place I knew, I grew a lot -but this was very difficult to see at the time. In retrospect, however, it's very clear to me that this has shaped me in a positive manner. I would suggest talking to somebody about you depression, loneliness and anxiety. I know it's not easy to open up to people, especially when you feel "alienated" to begin with, but you should give it a go. Just keep in mind that you might have to see several psychiatrists before finding the right fit for you. Although I don't know you, or anything else about you than the information in this comment, I know that we're all stronger than be believe and we can pull through. Find a light and start walking towards it, never let it out of your sight, but if it slips.. keep walking anyway, if you bump into a wall you just turn and walk the other way until you find your way out - you can do it. /hug

INSIDE OUT - MOVIE REVIEW (Spoiler Alerts!) I watch it and it was beyond my comprehension. This movie is so smart, funny, insightful & sad (like, seriously sad... T.T). I think this cartoon is not just an ordinary kids movie, rather, more suitable for grown-ups, especially those who struggling with their own crowded minds. I read somewhere, some psychiatric even try to connect the message from this movie with Autism and Depression. Tough subject for kids cartoon, right? There's one cute character named Bing-Bong, he not even mentioned in the trailer, yet his part is so grandiose & touching. Prepare yourself, Bing-Bong gonna put a big painful lump in your chest & lung while you watch (or can't even). There's so many sad moments in this movie, too sad for kids, yet, I think, it will relieving for the adults. Since we don't have many chance to cry nowadays... Nevertheless, the sad parts is equal with the funny & happy parts. There's many smart dialogue & plot that you can't even point out. Who knows a mind of 11-year old girl named Riley could be that astonishing heartbreaking...? I love Joy so much, and her joy in this movie isn't the ignorant one. She try to be happy all the time for the sake of Riley. So when Joy became sad at the centre of the movie, you really need to grab lots of tissues, FAST. Whoever you are, you should watch Inside Out: Highly recommended, it's funny, shocking, happy, sad, smart & even terrifying in some pivotal parts. 10/10 for Pixar. Love it!!

To the people who ask why they chose the emotions they chose, like disgust, etc. There's a reason why. In Psychology, you learn that a human is born with 6 natural emotions - Happiness, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust, as well as Surprise. They are programmed in your brain right away and those are the only 6 you start off with. All other feelings, such as jealousy, envy, hatred, anxiety, mischievousness, etc. even love are learned emotions you pick up growing up.

(Spoilers) I looked at DABDA, and Riley goes through it pretty consistently. First, Joy was trying to make it seem better than it actually was, a kind of Denial. Then, Riley got angry with her parents at dinner, her friend, and when she stole her parents' credit card. She bargained (in a certain point of view) with the subway online to get back to her old home. She lost her personality islands, showing signs depression. Riley also lost all emotion when the control panel went black as she was sitting in the bus, showing full-scale depression. Sadness got her off and as she went home, she accepted it (although sad and crying). Later, she seemed okay with her new home. And so, she had Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and Acceptance.

I think (if they do) if they make a second one, it could be told by her as a high schooler, or from a boy (little boy at the end). They could add new emotions (Tired, Sick, Regretful, Dramatic, Embarrassed) and the problem is that now there is a "president of emotions" (love) and she/he goes to the headquarters (OH! I just realized that pun!) and that the little boy and Riley are now dating. The love emotion is supposed to help her keep her love emotion. But love accidentally loses her love feeling and now the team has to get them back together. Just a thought :)

And director stated that the only reason why Riley's is mixed emotions is due to his own gender biases thinking some emotions just seemed more masculine with others being more feminine. But mostly he wanted more cohesion with the scene so he made the parents' emotions one gender for clarity. As the director said, it's essentially 16 characters in 4 different settings in the span of a few minutes so he wanted the parents emotions to be easier to identify. By having the father 's as male with mustaches and the mother's with her hairstyle, we could easily identify which emotion belonged to who when the scene changed. http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Why-Inside-Out-Main-Character-Has-Male-Female-Emotions-72176.html http://scifi.stackexchange.com/questions/93997/why-are-two-of-rileys-five-emotions-in-inside-out-male

Let me start off with this: when I first saw the first trailer for this movie, and heard its premise, I thought it would just be effing awful. I wrote off the whole movie just based on the fact hollywood was making a movie that dealt with themes of youth mental health. But after watching the trailer I really think this movie is going to give me feels on so many levels, I'm actually crying watching it. lol As someone who has been dealing with mental health issues their whole life, grew up in the awful Children's Aid Society of London and Middlesex, and has been mistreated their whole life by society because of awful misconceptions and stigma towards people with mental illness, I want this movie to succeed. I'm afraid it wont, and I'm afraid the humour and messages will fall so flat... That being said, this trailer made me actually cry. I actually am crying as I type this. I hope this movie turns out great, it could really be something really cool. I think Pixar is one of the only studios in the hollywood industry that could handle the issue of youth mental health with tactfulness, yet still be humourous. There were lots of moments in the trailer that just made me smile, and that I could totally relate to.

replies.commentText: +ShaunsBlogs Well actually, psychology has 6 main emotions. These 5 and suprise. So Disgust is surprisngly one of the main emotions. And even though the feelings are negative, they actually help riley. Disgust makes sure that Riley doesnÂ´t get poisoned, mentally or physically. Anger makes sure everything is fair for Riley. Fear makes sure Riley is safe.

+luisgarza1000 yeah I'm not saying the negative ones aren't important. All I'm saying is that it would be nice to see another positive. And yeah I think the disgust choice makes more sense to me now. They were probably going to go with all 6 but cut Surprise as he wouldn't bring anything to the table that fear and joy could.
+ShaunsBlogs I think love is a form of joy.
+Troll Breaker Love is connected to discipline, sacrifice, responsibility and patience. I think lust is more easily connected to joy.
+Maiq TheLiar So, love would actually be fear?

+ShaunsBlogs Disgust as just the simple word sounds like a pretty unimportant emotion, but thinking about it, Disgust might actually be pretty strongly tied to having good morals. Like when you see people doing something that could be considered "disgusting" - like maybe littering, bullying other people, treating animals cruelly, etc. Disgust is what tunes you in to the fact that that type of behavior is, in fact, disgusting, and would thus keep you from behaving that way yourself. And as shown in the film, Disgust is also what lets us know what type of behavior is acceptable in different social situations. If there were no Disgust, there'd be nothing to keep Joy from pouncing on people or Anger from ripping people's heads off.
She should've been named "Attitude" instead.

I'm thinking I'll see it again this weekend. +Justa G Pretty much. I've seen plenty of perfectly enjoyable popcorn films over the last year or so, but this was the first film I've seen in theaters in a long time that's actually felt like it had a decent amount of depth and meaning to it. Sadly, that's pretty rare in Hollywood these days.
+Josh Leitzel Yeah, Avengers: Age of Ultron was awesome, but Inside Out was great on another level. And I always appreciate a G-rated movie that treats its audience with some sense of maturity.

While watching AoU for the second time I remembered that it was one of those movies that is most enjoyable to watch the first time through, what with all the zippy quips and bombastic set pieces. After that, while it may still be a really fun movie, there just isn't much more for you to discover or dissect during a second viewing. So yeah, Inside Out was the exact opposite of that. BTW: It's actually PG. But I get your point. I've long defended that just because a game is rated E or a movie G/PG, that doesn't mean it should just be discounted as children's fodder. Most people who try so hard to prove that they're adults are nothing more than children in grown up bodies themselves. True adults can accept and enjoy quality art when they see it. They don't care about how mature it makes them appear. Pixar knows this, Nintendo knows this, Studio Ghibli knows this. Not a lot of others do.
+Josh Leitzel Well then, it's the first PG animated kids movie I've seen in awhile that didn't run on crude humor.

+Tania Minaz +Raineer Guialal +Angel Feronica +Justa G C'mon, guys. Inside Out is still in theaters. Just contribute to its success now instead of watching cam-rips. If you seriously don't want to pay to watch this movie, at least wait until it comes out on DVD and Blu-ray so you can at least watch a decent bootleg. Which you shouldn't even need to do because most libraries stock these movies within the first few weeks of release. Not to mention Redbox and Netflix-style style streaming and rental services that let you pay a fraction of the ticket/DVD/Blu-ray price to watch the movie after its theater run. I don't advocate piracy, but I see the appeal if it's a movie you don't want to contribute to. For instance, I waited until I could rent Frozen from Redbox to see it because I didn't want to contribute as much to the massive ball of money Disney was raking in from essentially a music video that wasn't as innovative as it was made out to be AND had already made an insane amount of money. No offense, but you must not know much about genetics. Everybody carries a trait from their mom and dad in all of their features. This means that your eyes have two chromosomes, one from your mom and one from your dad. It is possible for a brown eyed person to carry the blue eyed chromosome, and if both of Riley's parents carried this chromosome, there would be a 25% chance Riley would have two brown eyed chromosomes, a 50% chance she would have both chromosomes, and a 25% chance she would have 2 blue eyed chromosomes, in which case the recessive blue eyed trait would appear. Okay, so I'm excited for this movie. I think it's definitely very emotional and deep if you're open minded and can interpret things on a deeper level. So Sadness seems to be the main emotion that nobody really likes, although Joy tries to be friendly. So when Joy and Sadness get lost, Riley mostly feels Anger, Fear and Disgust. In my mind, I think this shows that when people are so down they try to block out a certain emotion, such as joy, love, sadness, etc., these emotions almost kinda get lost deep inside you, causing your other emotions to take over instead. For instance, if you're broken hearted and you block out the emotion of love, then when another situation comes up where somebody likes you, then you're angry because you don't want to get feelings, or you're fearful because you think they'll leave or you're confused of why they even bother to acknowledge you. So blocking out one emotion enhances your others to take over. All of them together can balance each other out. You need them all. I think that's what this movie is meant to portray on a deeper level.

Ok, I really want to see this. Not just because of the original story concept, but to see how Joy and Sadness work off each other. Also, I'm really curious to see how they justify being sad. From the looks of the trailer, it seems that Joy is sort of the "big dog" in Riley's emotions and Sadness just wants to feel as important and special. When she touched one of the core memories, I can't help but think that maybe it was originally a sad memory, but then Joy made it a happy one, so that when Sadness touched it again, it took on it's true form. (Something like that, I don't know). Really, Sadness is the only emotion that's sort of hard to defend. Joy is obvious because happiness is positive energy. Fear stops you from doing foolish things (i.e. you don't run out into traffic because the thought of being hit by a car is a scary thought. Common sense, I know, but it's linked to fear). Anger, when controlled, can actually be a confidence boost and make you want to stand up for what you believe in. Like being angry against a bully. Disgust...well, I guess disgust can be like fear where it stops you from doing stupid stuff and can lead you to wiser choices. But Sadness can be tricky. I mean, no one LIKES being sad, unless it's a stress relief to cry. Anyone care to comment? (Not trying to star a flame war. I'm just curious to see what people say.)

Yeah,I feel like if it was developed right, it could end up being a really powerfully tear-jerking thing, especially since seeing as the Emotions are relatively the same throughout Riley's life, they'd kind of be forced to watch as Riley's mind deteriorates from whatever illness it is, and they have to help her through it.
+airbendingavatar1 Indeed. Can't wait for the movie.

I'm really interested to see how the story progresses and ends. How does the inner world affect the outer and vice versa? How does the loss of Joy & Sadness affect the girl and does something happen to the girl to get them back? Since this for kids to see, I doubt there will be drugs used.

Based on the fact that things start to look dark at the part of the trailer where Fear says "Nothing's working, why isn't it working?", I'm guessing that Headquarters, and maybe Riley's entire mind, begins to shut down/go haywire as Riley's emotional state gets worse and worse. As an interesting note, this is the first Pixar film to be rated PG not for rude humor, but rather sensitive subject matter (I dont think thst's the right phrase used, but something that is in essence that). Drugs likely won't be involved, but I do feel like the movie could get pretty heavy.

+airbendingavatar1 I wonder what caused Riley's mind to go haywire. Is it some traumatic experience or just caused by the little emotions? It'll be interesting to see how those emotions work as both a character and well, "emotions". Could they possibly make Sadness seem likable? The possibilities with this set up are endless.

Based on what I know from the trailers and such, I'm guessing it's a combination of both. With Joy and Sadness gone, the only emotions Riley is capable of strongly feeling are Anger, Disgust, and Fear. So she ends up acting on those emotions' presences, and that likely gets her into trouble. Not to mention Sadness can turn happy memories sad on accident, so Riley could get more and more depressed or unstable if that happens. I even saw someone on TV Tropes guess that if Sadness turns more happy memories sad on accident, Riley might try to attempt suicide (though I highly doubt Pixar would go that far). Also, at least according to the Disney Wikia (this may have been added by oneone who saw one of those hour screenings, idk), but if those edits are true, Riley is somewhat neurotic and one of her dislikes is being called a freak or a psycho.
+Pika Boy Power or a brain transplant.

commentText: This looks terrible

replies.commentText: How does this look terrible? It's original, it has humor(Anger will probably get the most laughs), the characters are instantly lovable, we get to see the unique places Riley's mind(I mean seriously Dream Productions! A movie studio that makes dreams! That's pure Pixar imagination), and it looks like it will have a lot of emotional moments. Plus it's from Pete Docter the director and writer of both UP and Monsters Inc!

The animation looks a bit off IMO. It looks like they were going for a more "realistic look" but failed. Everything looks animated but doesn't have the same nice look like Frozen and Brave had. Also it has potential but you can't believe this WILL be amazing. Brave and Toy Story 3 were good but not like classics or anything.

+John Smith Pete Docter stated the emotions are made out of pure energy particles they are able to squash squish stretch and do other "cartoony" things other Pixar characters couldn't do. Also you CAN beileve this will be amazing especially since the director and writer is responsible for some of Pixar's best films. And Toy Story 3 (in my opinion and probably many other people) is a classic. Brave personally I could care less for.

+Steve ross The art direction looks off not the animations. For me its harder to look at. Also although a great director and writer is working on it DOESNT mean it will be good. It just means it will most likely be good.

+John Smith Well I beileve it will be great probably even amazing. Even people who saw early screenings said it was fantastic. As for the art direction like I've said before their going for a whimsical Tex Avery style.Which is why the characters act in a "cartoony" manner. You'll notice it more when Joy and Sadness travel deeper into places like Imaginationland or the yet to be revealed Abstract Thought which looks like a Picasso type world. The film is described as a fun road trip through the mind.

replies.commentText: How does this look dumb and unentertaining? It's original, it has humor (Anger is probably going to be the most funniest character), it's showing us the unique places inside Riley's mind, and it's going to have it's emotional moments. Plus it's from Pete Docter the director of both UP and Monsters Inc. Then again if you look at Pixar's past trailers they do sometimes make the movie look a little dumb (this one didn't). For example if you watch the first trailer for UP you could've easily thought that the film was just going to be about a man tying balloons to his house. You didn't know you'd be crying in the first 15 minutes. Another example would be the trailer for the first Toy Story. EVERYONE thought it was going to bomb and be awful now look at it! It's a masterpiece! Heck! Even people thought WALL-E wasn't going to be good because the trailers didn't have any dialouge from the main character. Basically what I'm saying is just because something looks dumb and unentertaing doesn't mean that it is dumb and unentertaing.

+John Smith Well, (Apparently this is going to be one of the morals in the movie at some point) fighting to prevent yourself from being sad doesn't help anything. It's okay to be sad, and you even need it sometimes. Yes, it IS bad to constantly be sad, but if you never are, your body and mind will never get the chance to sit back, relax, and figure things out for a while. It's completely natural to be sad. True strength is allowing yourself to be sad since you know you have faith you'll get better, and you'll likely learn something about your behavior, the behavior of others, what constitutes as moral, etc. My main emotion almost all the time is extreme joy and happiness, but it's true that it's healthy to be sad. +Boo Boo "everything was so predictable. The story and animation were both generic. If one would watch it without prior knowledge about the animation studio, i guess many would say that it was a Dreamworks film." So you are saying that DreamWorks do generic films... Let's ignore that, I know the animation was better in HTTYD2 but the movie overall was much weaker. As for predictablity... They were both predictable. DreamWorks always has the long lost family members making appearances in their sequels so I knew Hiccups mum was bound to show up. Just look and Shrek or Madagascar. As for the pack of Dragons being found and therefore threatened... That's basically the plot of Rio 2. As for Big Hero 6, I knew the bad guy was obviously the professor but I had no clue why. That kept me trying to guess the entire time. "I don't wanna discuss about the death/s of BH6 and HTTYD2 but the latter had more impact for me." Losing a loving brother over a dead beat dad is always going to be more painful. I mean Hiro spends the entire movie trying to get over it. Hiccup is over it by the next scene. But even the death of Baymax at the end was tear worthy and he isn't even a living character. "The villain in BH6 had no development at all" Um are you kidding me? Callaghan was a scientist who worked on creating teleportation with this corporate fat cat named Krei. One day Krei wants to test out the device before Callaghan feels it is ready but Krei insists. Callaghan's daughter is the test subject and obviously the project fails. Callaghan blames Krei for this and vows revenge. He spends his time as a professor, putting his mind to good use and waiting for an oportunity to get his revenge. At the science show a boy named Hiro presents him with that chance. It is a simple revenge story with a cool twist that we (well clearly not us per se but most kids) thought he was dead, only to find out he was alive this whole time. In getting his revenge he not only almost killed several people and did kill one of his most beloved students. He was so blind to his goals he never noticed the people he was hurting. Then in his final scene where the police are taking him away he sees his daughter is alive meaning he truly was in the wrong and you see that on his face. They put a lot of thought into this character. Much more than the dragon enslaver dude who was just wanting more power. That was a total one note character. "Also, the movie failed to focus and balance Hiro and Baymax." I disagree completely. The relationship between these two characters was amazing. I still fist bump people and go "fa la la la" afterwards because of this film. Hiro alone is this amazing child genius who can create pretty much anything he sets his mind to and Baymax is this big, loveable blob of cuteness who wants to help people. I'm not saying Hiccup and Toothless weren't a great team but Hiro and Baymax are just as good. "But overall, Kaguya-hime and Song of the Sea were better films". Didn't see either of them but I'm sure they weren't. I love anime and I've seen and own more than I can count (It is currently in the 100s). But Anime films usually lack when it comes to story telling. They start off strong but will fizzle out by the end. Their ideas and animation are outstanding but the actual structure of the story is lacking. Not even Studio Ghibli manage to be strong the whole way through and those films are considered the Disney of Japan.

+dragonrings14 you cried over a guy who we barely get to know? And then you call Hiccup's dad a deadbeat? I already lost you. I disliked BH6. The entire time I was watching it I just criticized it with my sister. I guess it just wasn't for me. Big Hero 6 also had those annoying lame supporting characters. Like, in the book they were all Japanese but in the movie they're different races in order to provide for diversity and representation and crap. They all have one dimensional personalities as well, maybe they'll flesh them out in the sequel? The supporting cast in HTTYD were far superior even better in the sequel. So and so that they didn't even feel like supporting characters but rather like actual people. Baymax and Hiro had a good relationship. Even though Hiro is the only one with self awareness. Also BH6 kills off a character early on so it kind of gets forgotten later on. HTTYD2 does it in the middle, adding to the obligatory drama portion of the movie. ALSO, the characters in HTTYD2 were far more likable. The ones in BH6 were either all too smart or too rich for me to get down with. I guess maybe that was it's target audience but I didn't like it. While HTTYD was more for me. I used to be an honors student myself until I realized what terrible people most smart kids were. And no I'm not gonna get into that.

+Angelo Cruz No I didn't cry over any of these deaths. I know some people are too emotionally involved in films and cry but I'm not. Except Mufasa (I'm not made of stone). But you act like I barely knew Tadashi and therefore I shouldn't cry over his death. I knew he was the eldest brother of two, who loved and looked out for his little brother. As their parents died while they were young, Tadashi had to step up and try be a good male role model for Hiro. He was a smart, hard working boy who wanted to use his knowledge to help people and make the world a better place. He had a loving aunt and kind friends who thought the world of him. He was clearly a good person and was taken from this Earth too soon. Hiccups dad whose name escapes me (googling it) Stoick is a terrible father. He thinks his son is worthless to him unless he is a warrior. He puts all this pressure on Hiccup to the point where Hiccup is risking his life just to impress him. I mean the dragons could have killed Hiccup a dozen times in that film (the first one). Sure they turned out to be good but Stoick doesn't know that. Stoick is also never around to raise Hiccup. No that is left for Gobber to do. Gobber I might add is the only one in the entire village that believes in Hiccup. He raises him, lets him go through training and isn't completely gob-smacked when it turns out Hiccup can be of use to the village. If they'd killed off him then I'd have been upset. Plus Stoick risked his life every day. Not to sound totally heartless but he had lived a full life by then. Hiccup is 20 in that film (the second one), putting his dad in his 40s. That is a long life for a Viking. As for the supporting characters, cmon. You honestly found that there were any dimensions to the ones in HTTYD. I mean there was the pretty girl who might as well think our hero character is invisible, the jock rival who is obsessed with said pretty girl, the fat dumb one and the twins who can't get along with each other. I get HTTYD is very beloved but it was so cliche. I however didn't mind that because the relationship between Hiccup and Toothless is so good but please don't act like the other characters mattered. As for not liking the changes made from the BH6 comics, did you care about the changes made from the HTTYD books? Trust me, HTTYD isn't even close to its book counterpart. At no point do you forget about Tadashi's death. The entire film Hiro is grieving over it. Even at the end he doesn't want to lose Baymax because not only is he Hiro's friend but the only part of his brother he has left. He can't left go of him but knows he has to. That was the real tragedy. Again, Stoick may have died in the 2nd act but it was almost entirely forgotten about by the next scene. Hiccup was too concerned with losing Toothless because he loves that dragon way more than his father and so he should because Toothless, unlike his dad, has always been there for him.
+Deaths_Genesis yeah, i can get behind that.
+dragonrings14 oh I had no idea HTTYD was a book. I should check that out. You make good points. I still didn't like the cast in BH6 though

+dragonrings14 I was talking about the kind of animation Dreamworks does. There are lots of CGI movies that are the in the same, more or less, quality of animation in some Dreamworks film. So it was not the whole movie itself. Weaker? It was predictable and cliche but to say that it has a weaker plot compared to HTTYD2, I have to disagree with that. There's much more character development in HTTYD2 compared to BH6. That's the thing also, they just like put something to justify something without any development. It makes sense but it's not an unusual thing nowadays. I know that they both did well emotionally but it still subjective. You focused on one statement alone. Okay, for me it still pretty cliche to the point that it's not surprising nor have impact to me. And I doubt about putting a lot of thought into his character tho. It isn't that complicated for an amateur writer to think about it. Clearly, as i can see, you're just focusing in a certain sentence per paragraph that would make my comment unjustifiable. In HTTYD2, both Hiccup and Toothless are remarkable as partners and individuals. In BH6, they are both remarkable as partners. Baymax, individually, yes but Hiro, I doubt so. That's what I'm trying to say. Again, i said it as my opinion. Heck, i did not even tell you to like it at all. Anime films lack in storytelling? If that's your opinion, I respect that. But I think i have to discuss this more. First, Song of the Sea isn't an anime, it's an Irish animated film by Tomm Moore. It has a better plot than the two above and better storytelling. I have to ask what kind of anime do you usually watch? Of course, all animes are not perfect. There are some that's not really good. For me and many others, animes are great cause they can still hold the premise and improve it more as the story moves on, character development, even side characters are given importance that you can hardly see on its Western counterpart, etc. The "premise-strong, end-fizzle" type of movies? Those are mostly Western movies hahaha. They don't usually have focus or get lost with their plot. Could you please suggest me some animated movies that have the same or can even surpass the emotional impact that Wolf Children and Grave of the Fireflies gave? Nice thing that you brought up Studio Ghibli. Your last sentence was kinda disturbing. Are you trying to say that Studio Ghibli are nothing compared to Disney? And it's like it's not worthy to be considered as "Disney of Japan"? I like both animations but to say that SG isn't strong as Disney isn't "acceptable" lol. Financially, yes, SG has no match with Disney, but with quality, even though I like the two, i can say that SG is better. They both deliver touching movies but Disney is a more straightforward, a very child-friendly one. For me, it is SG that is more emotional because of its subtlety. The characters are great, Disney is more to Man vs Man while SG Man vs Nature vs Self. The settings in Disney are just mere settings. They give so much attention to their settings which they are really famous for. Every landscape evokes different emotion their, part of their subtlety. Storywise, Disney is more straightforward and because of this, sometimes, everything felt rushed and also most are cliche. SG is a slow-paced one. Other people find their movies sometimes in the second act as tedious but it's not something that you can call as fillers. All the wait are really paid off at the ending. Disney's endings are the happy ones. SG sometimes are happy endings when it comes to their more children-oriented films. Their more matured ones vary and sometimes not the happy endings fairy tales showed us. Disney films are children-oriented shows that can be enjoyed by the adults. Studio Ghibli caters not only the children but the adults also. One more thing, the beauty here is that because of SG's subtlety, different age groups have different interpretations and can evoke different emotions to their films than to Disney which is straightforward (I think this is my third/fourth time to say this lol), good for some nostalgic weekends. And last sighs, many say that Disney creates animated film for the sake of entertainment art whereas Studio Ghibli creates films as pieces of art as a whole. (Sorry, it's a mess I know. I just finished a test today that's why my brain is a mess now. And I'm sleepy hahaha)
Bad pixar movies: -Cars -Cars 2 -Brave
It's all a matter of opinion really. Personally, I loved Brave, but I can understand that a lot of people disagree.

+Boo Boo Holy crap that was a lot to read. But I will simplify it down to 3 points: 1) Big Hero 6 was a better film than HTTYD 2. But it was a very close race. I mean they both grossed roughly the same, are rated roughly the same and have numerous awards. It is basically like saying which of two $10 bills do you like the most. At the end of the day you have $20. Personally though, Big Hero 6 created this story about a 14 year old Asian-American whose bother (and best friend) dies so he clings onto Baymax, the only thing left that reminds him of his brother. That alone was better than a guy tries to take over dragon country by forcing dragons to obey his alpha so now Hiccup has to stop him. If this was the first HTTYD film it would be a bit harder for me but based on the second film it is obvious that Big Hero 6 is the winner. 2) I actually watch all kinds of anime. I have no particular taste unlike most Anime fans. I love it all. I just feel a lot of movies get lost in their story sometimes. Japanese story telling is very different to Western story telling. We prefer happy ending when the Japanese prefer sad ones. We are very black and white about good and evil but Japanese are very grey. It has a lot to do with our history, our legends, our religions. It is too much to go into but I feel the western execution is usually more satisfying. Not every time obviously but a lot of the time. 3) Studio Ghibli and Disney are both great.I could argue for hours about why Disney are still better though. I've seen every Ghibli film and not one of them would beat Lion King. Though some could come close.

+dragonrings14 1) Box office hit can't justify the quality of a movie. You are talking about the premise of both movie and i can also agree that BH6 has a better one. But even a promising premise isn't enough for a movie to be great, it's in the execution and progress of things and for me HTTYD2 did a better job. I'm not saying that BH6 did a poor job, it's good, satisfying esp for kids but not to the point of getting the attention of all ages. Like for me, it felt rushed after Tadashi's death. 2) May i know what are those movies? I'm not really a big otaku so I don't know and haven't watched other anime films. That's the thing, cultural biases. If you think it's less satisfying because of those reasons, it still can't justify that it failed on its execution or storytelling. Satisfaction is subjective thus it does not reflect the quality of the movie. For example, I am satisfied with the Transformers but overall, it's not a great movie. And what West lacks is most of their animated films are/were not courageous enough to give their audiences a bad ending. They are good but instead of pushing through the boundaries, they safely play inside the comfort zone. Minus the Pixar tho. One thing that I did not like about Pixar, let's say in Up, was the first act was so great until it became a comedic relief with talking dogs. But still, a great film. 3) You just said that you haven't seen Kaguya-hime and there's When Marnie Was There so no, you haven't watched all of their films. Of course, none could beat Lion King. It has its own merits but it's the same with saying has Disney given us films which has the same quality of Spirited Away? How about Grave of the Fireflies? The characters in Disney are either good or evil. Good wins over evil. Happy ending. That's the formula Disney uses all over the years. Studio Ghibli is much more realistic when it comes to their works. Characters develop because of the setting and its interactions with the other characters. SG's stories are much more compelling, thought-provoking. They justify how the closest antagonists they have become like this. They do not produce movies for the sake of entertainment alone. But at the end of the day, it's a matter of perspective and preferences. To sum it up, if Disney is a storybook, Studio Ghibli is a poetry.

+Boo Boo I'm a little bored of us talking in circles so I'm gonna answer it in a different way: 1) like either BH6 or HTTYD2 as long as you aren't one of those idiots that thought The Lego Movie deserved it then you are alright by me. 2) It isn't just a cultural thing. Yes I grew up with western storytelling but I've been watching anime since I was 5 and real gritty anime since I was 13. I'm quite well adjusted to both stories. Japan does amazing stuff, just usually not in their films. Their stories are always so much more complex and should be padded out into a series. That is why most anime is more than just one movie. Ever seen a series that was a movie first (or vice versa). The series is always far greater. 3) You know what I meant. I've seen every other film except that one. Studio Ghibli have some great films. My favourite is Spirited Away and not just because it was the first one of SGs I had seen but because it is a classic. Grave of the Fireflies is depressing and a tad too slow for my taste. It drags on a bit too much. A bit like Ponyo. Ponyo drags on a lot longer than it needs. There's a reason most films wont go 10 minutes without dialogue. People can be artistic but not at the cost of good story telling. Plus Studio Ghibli's artistic shock value lasts one film. After that, the animation factor lessens.

+dragonrings14â€‹ 1) Of course I'm not into Lego Movie. It's an entertainment film but not really to be considered as the best. I think it is overrated =/ âœŒ 2) it isn't just a culture thing but you can't deny the fact that it affects how we perceive things. And what type of movies and endings you are used to. As I have said, it's a matter of preferences. You may find it boring but not to everyone. And also, some anime films like One Piece's, most of them, if not all, were not canon. 3) Those were all your opinions about those three films. But about the reason? Culture thing again. West are more to action-packed and fast-paced movies. They are made to entertain everyone. Entertaining and simple as it superficially, but in a closer look, it felt rushed, characters underdeveloped, and it leaves too many plot holes. Japanese are more slow-paced which might be boring for the other people, esp in West. But everything's really well paid off example of that is how developed their characters are. And about story telling, West are more into telling, not showing. Most of the time, i felt forced to feel this certain emotion because the scene told me so. And West puts only certain parts in their movie where it should be emotional then after that, they're back to the fast-paced scenes. East, on the other hand, is more on showing not telling (in case of Studio Ghibli). They show you what's happening. It doesn't force you to feel this way. It's like they let their viewers to be free. Everything is subtle. That's why Studio Ghibli is more on a poetic style and more considered as art films why Disney as the bedtime storybooks and more inclined to entertainment.

+Boo Boo I think we understand each other. Japan just isn't the same as USA and can't really be compared. That is why they will never win the Oscar. But I would love a collab between Ghibli and Disney. Imagine the story potential of Ghibli, told by Disney in a CG drawn film like those from the 90s. God that would be amazing.

I felt Kiki's Delivery Service, something with very little creativing, was more entertaining because it was a story. A story about a girl trying to make it on her own. Was it great? +dragonrings14 Howl's Moving Castle was an adaptation of a novel of the same name but the plot was different. I can't say it's terrible cause I haven't seen it nor Kiki's. But if you're talking about simplicity, I have to say that My Neighbor Totoro is on the lead in that category. But what made so special was the execution, the development of the characters, the emotional depth of the story/characters that I haven't seen on any Disney films. And the 80s feels, that what makes Studio Ghibli unique. It seems that you don't know about this stuff and I advise you to learn more about the SG because using that argument would show your lack of knowledge about the subject matter. They don't use new technology as a new medium but rather use it to give "a little boost of elegance". Imo, Disney's simple, "Disney-cliche" stories, songs, etc are the things that made Disney to where they are right now, let alone that they are the pioneer in the animated films, esp hand drawn. But as a lover of both Disney and Ghibli, i can say that the former's animation cannot hold a candle to the latter. +Boo Boo First off, I am finding your comments rude but also just plain confusing. You claim I don't know my stuff but you haven't even seen all of their films. I know that 18 films is a lot to watch but I've managed 17 of them. Also just because I think Ghibli should update their animation a bit doesn't mean I don't get their films. They don't have to stop hand drawn animation to do this. The Little Mermaid was hand drawn and it was done better that Ponyo, a movie that came out 20 years after. Studio Ghibli can keep their quirky flavour but modernise the look. The 80s feel isn't what makes their company unique. It is what makes it unpopular. Even in Japan these films aren't always well received. Compared to the latest and greatest animation Japan is doing atm they don't even compare. What really makes Studio Ghibli worth watching is their unpredictablilty. No 2 films have ever felt the same to me. But with Disney you know you will get a great film. Oh and Disney isn't cliche, it's signature. They are their own style. Can you tell me the last time you were disappointed by a Disney film? I haven't read nor watched all books and films but i can say that i know more stuff than those who have read and watched it (like my friends, etc). Mark Twain once said, "Don't let schooling interfere with your education." Comparing The Little Mermaid to Ponyo just because they were both hand drawn is absurd. The word hand drawn itself is a broad word, there are different styles to it. If you compare them, why not include Song of the Sea also. It's about half-human and half-seal which is pretty related to mermaids and it's also hand drawn :) It seems that you are equating uniqueness to the success of something. Ghibli is popular in their own credits and one of those is their animation. It's my bad also to say 80s feels alone. I should have stick to the traditional. Have you watched Kaguya-hime? Imagine and compare other styles of hand drawing and even CGI and tell me if they have match against Isao Takahata's use of traditional Japanese way of drawing. How can you even compare the different animation style of Ghibli's, let's say Spirited Away to One Piece? Once again, it's subjective. I agree to that but Ghibli's different approach to their animation is what also sets them apart to Disney, etc. Others cannot put the same subtleties that Ghibli usually do. Their animation helps a lot in conveying the emotion of the characters, etc. Don't worry, I have seen them. I can't say i'm always impressed by Disney films. They also have some flopped movies. Cliche is different to "Disney-cliche" that's why I put a quotation marks there. And saying that it's their own style contradicts your argument against Ghibli's way of animation lol. If Disney can make it's own signature by making their own "Disneyfied cliche stories", then why question the different traditional animation approach of Ghibli? Disappointed? Bolt, Frozen, etc.

+Boo Boo Sorry but it's pretty bold of you to think you know more about a franchise without seeing/reading its products. If your friends have seen all the films and movies of Harry Potter they probably know a lot more than you. Unless they aren't ones to care about the franchise. Also both were hand drawn and have under water themes making them a bit easier to compare. Song of the Sea wasn't hand drawn. It was a 2D digitally drawn film much like Disneys films in the 90s. I never once compared Spirited Away to One Piece. I said modern animation. One Piece is from 1997 and they haven't updated that style. A modern anime that you have probably heard of is Attack on Titan. That was just visually stunning. No, see you still aren't getting it. You think I want Stidio Ghibli to change its style completey. If he is talking about the animation then he is right. It looks like a mix between a realistic and animated look. So it doesn't seem very appealing to look at. The textures and animation seem detailed and fluid but the aesthetics look like they needed more work.

+John Smith Pete Docter stated the emotions are animated to look like they are made out of pure energy particles but from a far they look solid. Because they are made out of particles they are able to squash, squish, stretch and do other "cartoony" things that other Pixar characters couldn't do (Anger shooting fire out of his head, Joy bouncing around, Sadness having tears coming out of her eyes in a "cartoony" manner and being able to ride on a cloud when she cries). It does not look terrible it looks fantastic. The style is inspired by Tex Avery.

The general look of the characters and surrounding environment looks a little bit off. IMO it is not as appealing compared to other Disney animated films. Everybody has a preference for what they think makes a animated film look good.

If Pixar pulls this off, it could be something amazing. If they don't...well then I will be really disappointed. This sounds like a nightmare for the writers. Everything that happens in her mind has to make some sort of sense because it has to connect with real-world things in a logical way. If done wrong, it could just seem like her mind is insane, or that what happens in her mind has no connection to her real-life actions. They have to create rules for this world that we can believe. If they don't get it just right, the audience could constantly call into questions the rules of the story and think "wait...this doesn't add up," or, "What's going on, again?" If they do it well, though, this could be a really thoughtful movie with a lot of depth, where everything happens for a reason and there's meaning in every action of every scene.

+philtorius (I accidentally did a bunch of research because I love this kind of stuff. Hopefully this isn't too long.) Well I guess you should look no further than Disney Animation Studios' past films. Maybe they haven't come out with "original" content lately, but in the past they've made films like... (*looks up the list of DAS films) Oh my god. You've totally got me there, dude. I just looked over their list of animated features, and technically, almost every one of them is based on a novel or an existing story or legend of some kind (actually, I think most films are probably based on something. You just don't always hear about it). There are a lot of original films, but it's a small percentage when you're looking at over 50 films. The only DAS movies completely free from any adaptation are segments of Fantasia , Many lesser known films made around WWII times, The Rescuers Down Under (The Rescuers was adaptation though), _The Lion King_ (but there's some controversy about its real origins), segments of Fantasia 2000 , Dinosaur , Lilo and Stitch, Brother Bear, Home on the Range (sigh), Bolt, and Wreck-It-Ralph. So I guess there's a testimony there-some really great films, and some one better left forgotten-, but if you're looking at a percentage of their films, it's a small one because they've made a lot of films. It's also worth noting that DAS has put so much originality and charm into their classic adaptations (think "Sleeping Beauty", "Bambi", and "Robin Hood") that they have taken over the legends on their own. When people think of those stories, the Disney version is the first thing in our minds. So it doesn't have to be completely original in conception to be "original" in execution.

+Boo Boo Sure thing. 1. Typical singular Disney princess protagonists changes to two. One of which is the sister of the other, and one of which becomes a queen. Disney has never had a queen protagonist. 2. We get more of a cataclysmic feel as the main issue could eventually lead to hundreds of deaths by extreme cold, if it remains unsolved. Most Disney princess (not all, but most) have low-scale problems compared to that of what Anna has to deal with. There are some who do have crazy problems like her (i.e. Mulan), but nothing else like this. 3. Soundtrack is nothing short of a masterpiece. Every song was notable, some of which got stuck in heads everywhere for a long time. 4. Two unpredictable plot twists which leaded to a more lovable ending for everyone. Not only with Hans' betrayal, but with Anna's sacrifice. We all assumed she was going to kiss Kristoff after the kiss with Hans wouldn't work. But that's not what happened. 5. First Disney princess/queen to posses magical elemental powers. Which, I might add, are also dangerous powers belonging to one of the protagonists. Never happened before. 6. First time the main character sang a love song with the villain. A very catchy, well thought-out song. 7. Have you ever seen a character created from magic that was a memory from the creator's childhood fun with their sister? Seems pretty un-clichÃ© if you ask me. 8. Certainly one of, if not THE most unique Disney princess we've ever seen. From her awkwardness to how she wakes up, she's definitely the best princess we've had in awhile. DEFINITELY not clichÃ©. 9. And finally, a Disney movie that teaches the importance of familial ties through a sibling relationship that has a GOOD reason not to be recognized. Luckily, as Anna taught us, these reasons are largely outweighed by true love.

+K-Town That should make an awful lot of sense, but what I find pretty confusing about the way these basic emotions are portrayed is that they have (slightly) nuanced personalities, which enables them to express a certain range of emotions (!) that go beyond the one they are supposed to embody. For instance, when a typically sad Sadness initiates an action, of course the kid will feel sad, but whenever Sadness is happier than usual (as we can see, she does smile a few times in the trailer), or if Joy sometimes happens to feels down while she's at the commands, then exactly what emotion does that come out as ? Do they kind of cancel each other, or mix together as maybe some kind of nostalgic longing ? Unless the emotions' emotions simply have no effect whatsoever on their human host as long as they keep pushing the right buttons...

+Faunatik You bring up a very valid point I didn't consider at first. It's easy to argue that Pixar wanted the emotions to have their own emotions, but in a more deeper philosophical level, does the sadness emotion exhibiting happiness affect its decision making? That is the core question because if it does affect its decision making, then it is valid to say the emotions have emotions because a sad emotion would never put the human in a position to be happy; that is a fault of definition. This I think goes along with you saying they need to push the correct buttons. Unless each emotion is parts of other emotions with a dominant emotion. Then every emotion is swayed more to a certain kind of decision, but is still likely to choose one not reflecting its dominant emotion. What I mean by that is for example: happiness is 50% happiness emotion, 25% sad, and 25% angry. So the happiness emotion is more likely to choose a happy decision rather than a sad one. I think this is the most plausible but would refute them being absolute. They still would be defined by their personalities, however, since their decisions are swayed to a dominant decision type. If sadness emotion exhibiting happiness doesn't affect it's decision making, then what they are showing is just part of a personality. We will have to watch the movie to find out. And great response btw!
It's possible that each emotion only has the emotion it controls e.g anger only has anger

commentText: So only 1 out of 5 emotions is a positive one. Wow.

replies.commentText: Joy is a pretty far-reaching one. Could probably cover a lot of positive emotions all in one.
+Lucas Thornton Yeah, but technically speaking a normal person's emotions aren't 80% negative.
She seems to be the leader so she could be worth like 60% or something. Of course in the end it's a movie and they can't make a character for all million emotions people feel.
As joy said, her memories are mostly happy. If we look at the memory library, we can see that most of it is golden color (which I assume they are happy memories), only some of them are other colored.
+You Win Yeap Well, it still probably would be more enjoyably, if say, disgust was replaced with pride or confidence.
but that is the strongest one
+Sputterbugz Nah I'm just mentioning it if you think about the character interactions.
What other positive emotions exist that's not covered by Joy? Joy may be one thing, but so is water in the human body, yet it take's up 60% space.
+Ariel Triton http://positiveemotionslist.com/images/PositiveEmotionList.png Joy covers all of that?

+DexDacozed I think the purpose was to simplify it as much as possible, since this is a family move aimed at children. Yeah, Joy doesn't cover all the possible positive emotions in the real world, but it you were the one making the movie and were told to pick the 5 emotions which needed to be portrayed, you couldn't really say "Okay, I want happiness, pride, confidence, excitement...or, and let's throw in a Negativity" because while the 4 positive ones I listed can be boiled down to Joy on a theoretical sense, Sadness and Anger and Fear and Disgust are too different from one another to be combined without sacrificing something (namely the consistency of portraying each emotion with roughly the same emotional range. In other words, they probably only have one positive emotion probably because you react the same way to most positive emotions fairly similarly (smiling), with minor differences coming in for more exact types, whereas the other four are completey different (crying and feeling down for sadness, fuming and loss of control with anger, nervousness and heightened instincts for fear, avoidance and...mild nausea for disgust, maybe?). It's not to mean that we have less positive emotion, as mentioned above, just that there's a lot more range to cover for the negative ones than for the positive. On that note, though, this is a movie which centers on a (pre-)teen girl, so it's not unrealistic to have her have a lot more negative emotions, being as hormones and social factors do make modern adolescence very moody fairly often, which is why her mind is more chaotic than her parents', who are already out of the adolescent stage and therefore have a better grip on their emotion most of the time. I do get what you're saying, though. I do kind of wish there was a higher range of positive emotions to feel, but the film makers had to go with what would make the most sense in comparison to a ultra-simplified version of the real world. Have a nice day/night now, and I hope your Joy is working overtime to bring you lot of positive feelings. ^_^

+Spiritvoice Yeah, I know all of that, and I don't want there to be 4 positive emotions either. Maybe a bit more balanced, like 2 positives and 3 negatives. Then again if they heavily focus on Joy only, I guess it won't be that bad. Kids can take more realism.
+DexDacozed The 6 basic emotions are anger, disgust, fear, happiness, sadness and surprise. I find it quite weird that they left out surprise.
+Oskar RÃ¶nngren i think they either merged surprise with joy or figured surprise would be redundant with fear being the one who's always shcoked.

+Oskar RÃ¶nngren betting on the former:D notice how joy is the only emotion that has two colors discounting outfits. he skin is gold while her hair is blue:D everyone else has hair the same color as their skin.
+Oskar RÃ¶nngren Oh, so that's where they got it from. I guess that makes sense then...

+DexDacozed None of these emotions are negative. They're all needed to function positively. Joy - Provides happiness and spontaneity Sadness - Gives you emotional depth and the ability to counteract the sometimes overly-free nature of joyDisgust - Allows you to dictate your likes and dislikes and form opinions Fear - Makes you think on your feet and avoid dangerous, or somehow threatening situations. Anger - Provides expression and passion against/for something, gives you the confidence to stand up for yourself and what you believe. The Ideal, in the world of the movie, I think, is to have all five working in harmony to feel an entire spectrum of emotions, and be the best person you can be. Notice that the mom and the dad have other emotions as their main "commander". Riley has Joy, Mom has Sadness, and Dad has Anger.

+Rabbyadam i didnt even notice that the parents had secific emotions leading themXD wonder if they have deeper meaning? like sadness makes the mother a more sympathetic individual while dad's anger makes him more stern and authoritative.

+Rabbyadam remeber reading about it in aritcles and at leats form tis trailer it seems the memories cna be affected by other emotions,like when sadness touched that happy memory of snow. :D i also remeber reading that pixar did hevay research into psychology and neurology to help make these metalscapes workable:D so i bet there is science behind emotion coloring memories:D
+Rabbyadam Well, they sure are more negative than positive.

+Rabbyadam Haha, sure, if you think about them in a positive way. You can say every emotion is positive then, as you can say every emotion is negative. However the 4 emotions lean towards negativity more.
+DexDacozed I really don't think so, but that's just my opinion :) You need sadness you appreciate joy.
+Rabbyadam Well, tell me a negative emotion then.

+DexDacozed Emotions are neither negative or positive, They just 'are.' It's how emotions affect us that form our opinions and lives. People say Hatred can only be bad. But hatred is what killed Hitler. Sure it's mostly associated with bad things. But Love, people only associate with goodness, but the Love some people have for their god/religion causes mass genocide. Don't you see, there are good and bad things about every emotion. When you feel Joyful, you dance around and feel fantastic, and you make rash decisions to continue feeling joyous and happy, and those rash decisions cause us to "get lost", or end up in bad relationships, or trust people we shouldn't, or make bad decisions with drugs and alcohol. All of those are connected with Joy and Pleasure. Emotions are neutral, it's just how and when we use them, that the connotation arises.
+Rabbyadam Wow what a sermon. So I guess nothing was ever anything.

+DexDacozed No, but EVERYTHING that we feel matters. I don't expect to make you appreciate fear or sadness. I just hope you realize we all feel things for a reason, and those reasons aren't always negative. Is it negative to fear bears and strangers when you're a kid? Not at all!
+Rabbyadam It's just that you make so many expectations wrong that I don't even bother to respond with actual thought.
+DexDacozed Then, you are even more sad and one-dimensional than I thought. I'm sorry you think of emotions in such singular, unfulfilling, unmeaningful parameters.

+Rabbyadam I never said that and now for some reason you just started firing shots. I really don't know what you're problem is but hey, I guess some people just like to talk shit about others because... reasons! Do enjoy.

It's not necessarily that the others are negativeâ€”they all have their role in protecting Riley: Anger: Makes sure things are fair for Riley Disgust: prevents Riley from getting poisoned physically and socially. Fear: Tries to keep Riley safe Sadness: no one knows what her role is and that will be explored in the movie. Though, as mentioned by the creators, if Riley gets into any physical danger, there's nothing the emotions can do to help, just affect her mind. Could be trouble for her.

+DexDacozed it's because of psychology, there are 6 unversal or basic emotions (http://www.nbb.cornell.edu/neurobio/land/oldstudentprojects/cs490-95to96/hjkim/emotions.html) that make up the more complex ones. I only took one semester of psychology, but I did study that. I'm guessing they didn't include surprise because it didn't work with the story they wanted to tell. The point is that they didn't put four "negative" (big quote marks) and only one positive one just for the sake of it, they did their research and worked on those concepts.
They didn't include Surprise because they felt Fear already covered that.
+airbendingavatar1 Actually they work in completeley opposite ways. Surprise leads to curiosity, fear makes you stay away from the unknown. Or at least that's what my profesor said.
+David Del Pozo FilÃ­u Yes yes, lots of people have already said that.
+DexDacozed I didn't read the whole thing, sorry if I was being repetitive. I kind of would have liked to be surprise, but I guess it is a very difficult character to write.

+DexDacozed In fantasy films things like sadness and fear often exist because of the forces of evil, but here they have to exist because Riley needs to feel sadness, anger, fear and disgust just as much as joy. In one of the other trailers, in an early scene when Riley is little, she avoids something dangerous because Fear tells her to. Joy isn't called a "positive" emotion in this because none of the others are "negative." If they were supposed to be bad, they'd be villains.
+Nyarl arthotep "Riley needs to feel sadness, anger, fear and disgust just as much as joy." Sounds like a sad life.

Not necessarily, they all have their role in guiding Riley:, Sadness: well, no one knows her role yet, but that will be explored in the movie as she and the other emotions learn more about it and Joy and Sadness appreciate each other Anger: makes sure things are fair for Riley Fear: keeps her safe Disgust: prevents her from getting poisoned physically and socially
